Award.AwardTitle: Bringing Galaxy Evolution into Focus by Pushing SED Models to the Limit
Award.AbstractNarration:
Joel Leja is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to conduct a program of research and education at Harvard University. Leja will build an accurate theoretical model to infer the physical properties of galaxies from astronomical observations. Understanding these properties will allow astronomers to gain a better understanding of how galaxies form and evolve. Alongside this research, Leja will provide science enrichment to middle school students through "reverse" science fairs, and he will serve as a mentor to minority undergraduate students to help prepare them for graduate studies in astronomy.

Leja will develop a realistic model to fit the spectral energy distribution of galaxies to better than about 50%. He will include the effects of active galactic nuclei in the model and calibrate it against well-studied photometric and spectroscopic galaxy catalogs. After full calibration, he will fit the model to nearly 10,000 galaxies spanning redshifts from 0.2 to 3.0 available in photometric catalogs. The fitting will yield the deepest, largest sample of self-consistent stellar masses and star formation rates to date and provide key constraints on feedback models of galaxy formation. For the educational component of his work, Leja will organize reverse science fairs where professional scientists will present their research to middle school students, and he will mentor minority undergraduate students in a summer program that prepares them for astronomy graduate programs through research and study experiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Joel Leja completed a three-year postdoctoral position supported through the NSF Astronomy & Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship program. He worked with the Conroy research group at the Center for Astrophysics | Harvard & Smithsonian to develop Prospector, a Bayesian statistical package which fits synthetic stellar populations to observations of galaxies.

The primary innovation of Prospector is that all models are generated on-the-fly while fitting, as opposed to from a pre-built grid of models. This permits higher dimensional models (up to 20-30 dimensions), compared with the ~7-10 dimensions that can be loaded into memory from a grid-based system. These more sophisticated models permit more complex physical behavior in galaxies, particularly in terms of their star formation history and the properties of the dust both surrounding and filling the stellar body of the galaxy.

Joel found that these updates change our understanding of the basic properties of galaxies: Prospector finds that, on average, galaxies have ~60% more mass in stars and are currently forming ~60% fewer stars. This directly changes our understanding of how galaxies grew through cosmic time. It implies that the universe of galaxies is both older and more quiescent than previously understood, with considerably more stellar mass being built in the first 3 billion years of the Universe's existence than previously expected. Using these results, Joel published a new census of the stellar mass of galaxies when the universe was between 2 and 11 billion years old.

Joel ran an annual Flipped Science Fair at the Center for Astrophysics | Harvard & Smithsonian as part of his broader impacts. At this event, professional astrophysics researchers at the Center for Astrophysics | Harvard & Smithsonian present their work to student judges at under-privileged middle schools. The students then judge their posters on intellectual content and communcations skills, and the winner of the event presents their poster to the entire student body. This event attracted hundreds of middle schoolers both years it was held. The third year, the event was cancelled due to the effects of COVID-19.
